thread.title: Art program sets Indigenous prisoners on a different path
thread.title_full: Art program sets Indigenous prisoners on a different path

author: Fiona Pepper
title: Art program sets Indigenous prisoners on a different path
text:
Map: Melbourne 3000 
The artwork of 145 Indigenous men and women who are currently or have previously served in the Victorian prison system is on display in Melbourne. 
The Confined 8 exhibition at St Kilda Town Hall is in its eighth year, running in collaboration with the Torch program. 
The program runs art classes throughout Victoria's prisons in hope of curbing the overrepresentation of Aboriginal people in the criminal justice system. 
Kent Morris, a Barkindji man, coordinates the program, and runs classes across Victoria's 13 prisons each month. 
"We go out to the prisons on a regular basis, bring in cultural resources and educational material to support men and woman to understand more about their language group," he said. 
"It's really about strengthening identity." 
Morris said the program could be extremely therapeutic for participants, often setting them on a path that prevents them from reoffending. 
"Once you understand who you are and your cultural identity you'll find your pathway," he said. 
In November 2015 the Victorian Government, in partnership with the Torch program, created a policy that allowed incarcerated participants to sell their art. 
Those on display as part of Confined 8 are also up for sale. 
The profits are then put into a trust fund that can be accessed upon their release from prison. 
"I've had men and women who would've been homeless upon release now having enough money to gain accommodation," Morris said. 'It's opened a lot of doors': Ray Traplin 
Ray Traplin is from far north Queensland and is part of the Kuku Yalanji mob. 
Currently living in Melbourne, Traplin was recently released from prison and is exhibiting a piece in the Confined 8 exhibition. Photo: Ray Traplin's Cape York Hunting Grounds illustrates what is hunted in different seasons. (Supplied: Torch Project) 
"[Art is] therapeutic because being incarcerated you've got a lot of time on your hands to do pretty much nothing and it gives you something to do, it fills the time in," he said. 
Having painted for the last 20 years, Traplin said he tells the stories of his country through his artwork. 
"A lot of people paint and the paintings don't really have a story or a meaning to them, whereas my work is based on stories told through the elderly that are passed down," he said. 
"It's something that I'll pass down to my kids one day through the paintings." 
Traplin was recently informed that one of his artworks would be displayed on a billboard in the Melbourne's CBD. 
"It's the next step in what I'm hoping to start a career in," he said. 
When asked if the Torch program was influential enough to prevent him from reoffending, Traplin responded: "Well, I think so, yeah, entirely." 
"I've found the Torch has helped strengthen what I want to do with my art. It's opened a lot of doors for me," Traplin said. 'Living the dream': Robby Wirramanda 
Robby Wirramanda is from Wergaia/Wotjobaluk country, in north-west Victoria, and was released from prison two years ago. 
While he was an established artist before being incarcerated, the Torch program allowed him to sell his artwork while serving his sentence. 
"I've been an artist since before I can remember, creating things with my grandmother," he said. 
He boasted that his artwork in the Confined 8 exhibition sold before opening night. 
"Both sold. They always sell — guaranteed, every time," he said. 
In Melbourne, Wirramanda ran mixed martial arts fights; now, he lives with his family in the bush near Swan Hill — and says he understands what "living the dream" really means. 
Wirramanda puts his drastic lifestyle change down to a change in environment. 
"I made some wrong choices at the time. I was trying to achieve too many things, too quickly and when you take shortcuts that's what happens," he said. 
"In the art world it's a totally different environment, surrounded by great people. 
"Like chalk and cheese, those two environments. It's definitely a different path."
